intro: Sisyrinchium vaginatum subsp. vaginatum, commonly known as the blue-eyed grass, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Iridaceae family and is characterized by its delicate, grass-like leaves and striking blue to violet flowers. The plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as meadows and rocky slopes. It produces small, tubular flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The subspecies is distinguished by its hairy leaves and the presence of a leafy sheath at the base of the stem.
